abstracts.cdata!:
The Institutional, Tax Administration,
            Social and Investment Development Policy Loans Project for
            Indonesia received a satisfactory outcome with a moderate
            risk to development outcome. Both the Banks and Borrowers
            performances were satisfactory as well. There are no
            recorded restructurings or major changes to this project.
            Three key lessons were learned from this project and are as
            follows: (1) The evolution of the core DPL program into
            three sectoral operations resulted in increased government
            ownership, a deeper Bank engagement on key topics, and an
            improved focus on the Governments most current priorities.
            This shift proved to be an effective strategy to advance the
            Governments reform program. (2) The extensive analytical
            work and technical assistance on poverty alleviation, shared
            prosperity, and PFM prior to the DPL were critical in
            identifying the reform program. (3) The presence of a strong
            government counterpart to serve as coordinator was an
            important success factor in a loan involving multiple institutions.
